Question 1 of 50 Question ID: 506112972

The project you are leading has a current CPI of 1.0 and SPI of 0.8. You have been notified by the project management office that your project has been selected for a quality audit that is scheduled to take place over the coming weeks.

What should be your primary concern with regards to the audit?

A
B
C
D

Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

A quality audit is among the tools and techniques of the Manage Quality process, which is concerned with translating the quality management plan into executable quality activities that incorporate the organization's quality policies into the project. A quality audit is a structured, independent process used to determine if project activities comply with organizational and project policies, processes, and procedures. Quality audits do not focus on the product or the project's schedule or cost performance. Therefore, of the choices available, ensuring that work complies with the company policies, processes, and procedures should be your primary concern.

One may argue that under the circumstances described in the scenario, with the project behind schedule, having an audit in the middle of project execution would be a hassle to the project manager, the team, the project stakeholders, and will likely put the project behind schedule even further. However, you, as the project manager, can do nothing about that. You have no choice but accept the fact the audit is coming and have to be prepared for it. So what will be your primary concern with regards to the audit? As mentioned above, quality audits do not focus on the product or the project's schedule or cost performance. Therefore, of the choices available, ensuring that work complies with the company policies, processes, and procedures should be your primary concern.



Details for Each Option:

A

Incorrect. Not every piece of information provided is actually relevant to the question. In this case, the project being behind schedule (as indicated by the SPI number) is an irrelevant issue, since quality audits are not concerned with the schedule or cost performance of a project but rather how the work being performed lines up with the policies, processes, and procedures of the organization.

B

Incorrect. Quality audits in Manage Quality do not focus on the product, but rather on the processes and their conformance to the quality management plan.

C

Incorrect. This sounds more like the activities that take place in the Control Quality process, which focus on determining if the project outputs are complete, correct, and meet customer expectations.

D

Correct. A quality audit is a structured, independent process used to determine if project activities comply with organizational and project policies, processes, and procedures.

      Question 2 of 50 Question ID: 506151471

      An organization has recently adopted an agile project management approach to carry out its projects. However, the stakeholders are dissatisfied with the quality of the deliverables and the speed of the product releases. An agile coach has been hired to improve the process. After analyzing the situation, the coach suggests several improvements to the team practices.

      What execution practices did the agile coach most likely suggest? (Drag and drop the items from right to left.)

      Continuous integration
      Timeboxed research or experiments
      Test at all levels
      Writing automated tests before developing the product
      Acceptance Test-Driven Development (ATDD)
      Frequent incorporation of work into the whole
      Spikes
      System-level testing for end-to-end information
      Behavior-Driven Development (BDD)
      Writing automated tests to meet pre-defined criteria
      Timeboxed research or experiments
      Writing automated tests before developing the product
      Frequent incorporation of work into the whole
      System-level testing for end-to-end information
      Writing automated tests to meet pre-defined criteria

      Correct Answer:

      Continuous integration
      Frequent incorporation of work into the whole
      Test at all levels
      System-level testing for end-to-end information
      Acceptance Test-Driven Development (ATDD)
      Writing automated tests to meet pre-defined criteria
      Spikes
      Timeboxed research or experiments
      Behavior-Driven Development (BDD)
      Writing automated tests before developing the product
      Frequent incorporation of work into the whole
      System-level testing for end-to-end information
      Writing automated tests to meet pre-defined criteria
      Timeboxed research or experiments
      Writing automated tests before developing the product

      Explanation:

      Quality of deliverables and speed of delivery are often interconnected. For example, if the quality of the product is low, the team would need to spend time fixing the product, thus delaying the product release. This, in turn, means the organization would deliver less value than what was originally planned for the project. eXtreme Programming (XP) may help mitigate this issue. XP is an agile software development method based on frequent cycles. Some of the XP practices help teams deliver value quickly while maintaining a high quality of the products.

      In the scenario, the stakeholders are dissatisfied by the quality of the deliverables and the low speed at which the team releases the product. While quality and speed are frequently seen as conflicting project constraints, some of the XP practices may help resolve the conflict or, at least, reduce its intensity, as described below.

      • Continuous integration refers to performing frequent incorporation of work into the whole and then retesting the product/deliverables to determine that the entire product still works as intended. Applying this practice help maintain quality without delaying the speed of delivery.
      • Testing at all levels means employing system-level testing for end-to-end information and unit testing for the building blocks. Teams analyze the system to identify points that require integration, smoke testing, regression testing, etc.
      • Acceptance Test-Driven Development (ATDD) is a practice in which the team determines the acceptance criteria of the product/deliverables and then creates the tests that drive writing just enough code and automated tests to meet these criteria.
      • Spikes are short timeboxed intervals within a project during which a team conducts research or prototypes an aspect of a solution to provide its viability or learn some critical technical or functional element. Spikes can be used for estimation, acceptance criteria definition, and understanding the flow of a user's action through the product.
      • Behavior-Driven Development (BDD), typically known as Test-Driven Development (TDD), is a technique in which the team writes automated tests before developing the actual product. This allows the team to continuously validate work in progress, enabling work with a zero-defect mindset.

      Exam Content Outline:

      Domain: 2. Process
      Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
      PM Approach: Agile / Hybrid

      +Reference:

      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES
      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.3.3 DEVELOPMENT APPROACHES
      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
      Agile Practice Guide - First Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2017, 5.2.7 EXECUTION PRACTICES THAT HELP TEAMS DELIVER VALUE
      Agile Practice Guide - First Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2017, A3.3 EXTREME PROGRAMMING
      End Exam

          Question 3 of 50 Question ID: 506125081

          An agile project team is developing a smartphone mobile app. The team members continuously integrate the software modules that comprise the app and use automated tests as part of their quality assurance processes. In spite of these efforts, the escaped defects rate has been increasing for the last two iterations.

          What should the project manager recommend to the team to help lower the defect rate?

          A
          B
          C
          D

          Correct Answer: A

          Explanation:

          Building quality in proactively as part of the product development process is far more effective than trying to catch defects reactively after the software has been developed. This proactive approach will have a positive impact on the quality of the product. eXtreme Programming (XP) is an agile software development method in which software code is written by two developers working as a pair. While one person writes the code, the other developer reviews the code as it is being written. This practice helps reduce defect rates as issues can be caught and corrected as the code is written. There are various practices that are attributed to XP. In the scenario, the team is already using two of them: continuous integration and automated testing. Pair programming, however, is not mentioned. Therefore, of the available choices, having the team members work in pairs while developing code will likely have a positive effect on lowering the defect rate and is, therefore, the best answer to the question asked.



          Details for Each Option:

          A

          Correct. In eXtreme Programming (XP), software code is written by two developers working as a pair. While one person writes the code, the other developer reviews the code as it is being written. This practice helps reduce defect rates as issues can be caught and corrected as the code is written.

          B

          Incorrect. Creating separate defect repair user stories and adding them to the product backlog is an acceptable agile practice. This approach ensures that defects are repaired. However, this course of action would not help lower the defect rate in the first place since this approach is not proactive.

          C

          Incorrect. Agile development methods take advantage of automated testing. Automated testing tools are typically more effective than manual testing. Replacing manual testing with automated testing tools is an effective method of reducing the defect rate, but not the other way around.

          D

          Incorrect. The scenario states that the defect rate has been increasing, implying that the defects are already being tracked. Therefore, tracking the defects using another tool would not benefit the team's process. Besides, tracking the defect rate is a reactive approach that, on its own, would not help reduce escaped defects. Note, the term "escaped defects" refers to the defects detected on the customer site ("escaped" to the customer). This knowledge, however, is not needed to select the correct answer or eliminate incorrect ones.

          Exam Content Outline:

          Domain: 2. Process
          Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
          PM Approach: Agile / Hybrid

          +Reference:

          A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES
          Agile Practice Guide - First Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2017, 5.2.7 EXECUTION PRACTICES THAT HELP TEAMS DELIVER VALUE
          Agile Practice Guide - First Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2017, A3.3 EXTREME PROGRAMMING

              Question 4 of 50 Question ID: 506112594

              A project manager wants to incorporate a continuous improvement approach throughout project execution.

              Which of the following actions is the project manager least likely to take?

              A
              B
              C
              D

              Correct Answer: A

              Explanation:

              The plan-do-check-act (PDCA) cycle is the basis for quality improvement as defined by Shewhart and modified by Deming. In addition, quality improvement initiatives such as total quality management (TQM), Six Sigma, and Lean Six Sigma may improve both the quality of project management as well as the quality of the end product, service, or result. A project retrospective is conducted at the end of the project to learn what can be improved upon for future projects. Since the project retrospective does not occur until the end of the project, it will not be beneficial in establishing continuous improvement for the current project. Note, the question is asking for the action which is 'least' likely to be beneficial in improving project performance throughout project execution. Therefore, of the available choices, holding a retrospective meeting at the end of the project is the best answer to the question asked.



              Details for Each Option:

              A

              Correct. A project retrospective is conducted at the end of the project to learn what can be improved upon for future projects. Since the project retrospective does not occur until the end of the project, it will not be beneficial in establishing continuous improvement for the current project.

              B

              Incorrect. The plan-do-check-act (PDCA) cycle is a methodology which establishes an iterative process to improve performance. The PDCA cycle is a common approach to continuous improvement.

              C

              Incorrect. A six sigma process is one in which 99.99966% of the results of a process are free of defects. A Lean Six Sixma Black Belt is an individual that has been trained and certified in the Lean Six Sigma methodology. Both are used to continuously improve the quality of project management, as well as the quality of the end product, service, or result.

              D

              Incorrect. A Deming cycle is also known as a plan-do-check-act (PDCA) cycle. A Deming cycle is a common approach to continuous improvement which establishes an iterative process to support performance improvement.

              Exam Content Outline:

              Domain: 2. Process
              Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
              PM Approach: Predictive

              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.5.8.1 Knowledge Management
              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3.1 Cost of Quality

                  Question 5 of 50 Question ID: 506112521

                  You meet with your team and key stakeholders to decide on what approach, waterfall or agile, should be used for your project. You explain to the meeting participants that continuous improvement is of utmost priority for the project. Someone asks you how waterfall methodologies compare with agile as it relates to continuous improvement.

                  How should you respond to this question?

                  A
                  B
                  C
                  D

                  Correct Answer: C

                  Explanation:

                  There is a fundamental difference between how lessons learned are managed on projects that use a waterfall-based methodology compared to those projects that have chosen an agile approach. At a high level, agile teams tend to be a lot more focused on continuous improvement and will review performance more regularly. Agile projects conduct retrospectives at the end of each iteration (typically two weeks to one month), which provides a more structured and proactive approach to continuous improvement. A retrospective is an example of a meeting, tool or technique used during the Control Quality process to drive continuous improvement. Additionally, agile team retrospectives can focus on the team’s working practices – how they work together, celebrating a job well done, bettering the relationships in the team, and often a more traditional approach focuses on the project tasks and deliverables and not how the team performed together.



                  Details for Each Option:

                  A

                  Incorrect. Waterfall project management approaches typically review project lessons learned towards the end of the project. Any lessons learned during project execution are captured on a reactive basis as they occur. The agile framework takes a more proactive approach by conducting retrospectives at the end of each iteration (typically two weeks to one month) and the end of the project.

                  B

                  Incorrect. Agile projects conduct both iteration and project retrospectives. Project retrospectives are conducted at the end of the project and review performance and lessons learned for the whole project. In projects managed using waterfall methodologies, retrospective (lessons learned) meetings are typically held only at the end of the project.

                  C

                  Correct. Agile projects conduct retrospectives at the end of each iteration (typically two weeks or one month) and the end of the project. This methodology provides a more structured approach to continuous improvement where continuous improvement is an integral part of project execution.

                  D

                  Incorrect. Agile teams tend to be more focused on continuous improvement and will review performance more regularly. Agile team retrospectives focus on the team’s working practices and processes, while a more traditional approach often focuses on the project tasks, deliverables, and individual team members and not on how the team performed together.

                  Exam Content Outline:

                  Domain: 2. Process
                  Task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
                  PM Approach: Agile / Hybrid

                  +Reference:

                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES

                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.2.2 PROJECT TEAM CULTURE
                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.2.3 HIGH-PERFORMING PROJECT TEAMS
                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.3.4 CONSIDERATIONS FOR SELECTING A DEVELOPMENT APPROACH
                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.5.3 MAINTAINING PROJECT TEAM FOCUS
                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY

                      Question 6 of 50 Question ID: 506125061

                      You are leading an agile software development project. During a sprint review, the customer rejects the deliverables stating that the grade is acceptable but not the quality.

                      Of the following, which might be the best course of action?

                      A
                      B
                      C
                      D

                      Correct Answer: D

                      Explanation:

                      The question indicates that the grade of the product is acceptable, but the quality is poor. 'Quality' and 'grade' are not the same concepts and are often confused. Quality refers to "the degree to which a set of inherent characteristics fulfill requirements" (ISO 9000 [18]). Grade as a design intent is a category assigned to deliverables having the same functional use but different technical characteristics. In this scenario, the quantity of features (grade) is acceptable while the quality of the deliverables is poor, which may be represented by the number and/or severity of defects. Therefore, of the available options, introducing more rigorous testing during the next sprint to reduce bugs is the best course of action in this scenario. Note, the scenario indicates that the project is lead by agile methods, where frequent quality and review steps are already supposed to be built in throughout the project rather than the end of the project. However, it seems that the current quality assurance activities have been insufficient. Hence, introducing more rigorous testing from the next sprint onwards will likely help to address the issue.



                      Details for Each Option:

                      A

                      Incorrect. There is no information presented by the question to suggest that the project is running behind schedule. The question indicates that there is an issue with the quality of the product. Increasing velocity without taking any other action is not likely to improve the quality of the deliverables.

                      B

                      Incorrect. While quality is an issue in this scenario, removing some of the features may not be acceptable to the customer. Having a robust set of features is an example of a higher-grade product. Reducing the number of features may make the grade unacceptable regardless of what happens with quality.

                      C

                      Incorrect. The quantity of features is an example of the product grade. The question states that the grade was acceptable but not the quality. Increasing the number of features, without any other action, is not likely to improve the quality of the product.

                      D

                      Correct. A high level of defects (commonly referred to as bugs in software) is an example of poor quality. Introducing more rigorous testing should improve the quality of the product by reducing the quantity and severity of the defects.

                      Exam Content Outline:

                      Domain: 2. Process
                      Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                      PM Approach: Agile / Hybrid

                      +Reference:

                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES

                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3.1 Cost of Quality
                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 3.3.2 PROCESSES
                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 3.5.5 PROJECT WORK
                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 3.6 DIAGNOSTICS

                          Question 7 of 50 Question ID: 506112510

                          You have been assigned to lead a drug development project for a small pharmaceutical company. The drug development aspect of the project is characterized by a high degree of uncertainty, complexity, and risk. The governmental approval process, on the other hand, is highly structured and well defined.

                          What project management approach would you recommend for this project?

                          A
                          B
                          C
                          D

                          Correct Answer: A

                          Explanation:

                          The scenario describes a project with two very different phases. The drug development phase, being characterized by a high degree of uncertainty, complexity, and risk, is well-suited to an agile project management framework. Governmental approval is described as a highly structured and well-defined process, which is best suited to a predictive approach. It is important to remember that it is not necessary to maintain a single approach throughout the project. In some cases, it can be advantageous to combine different life cycles in order to best support the needs of the project. Thus, a hybrid approach using agile for drug development and a predictive framework for the governmental approvals provides the best strategy to manage the project.



                          Details for Each Option:

                          A

                          Correct. In this scenario, the drug development phase, which is characterized by a high degree of uncertainty, complexity, and risk is well-suited to an agile project management framework. Whereas, the governmental approval process would benefit from a predictive approach.

                          B

                          Incorrect. The scenario indicates that drug development will have a high degree of uncertainty, complexity, and risk. These aspects of the project would be better served with an agile approach rather than predictive. Additionally, projects that are highly structured and well defined are better suited to a predictive approach rather than agile.

                          C

                          Incorrect. The project might benefit by incorporating the Kanban method. However, Kanban best practices seek to limit rather than maximize work in progress (WIP).

                          D

                          Incorrect. Crystal is a family of methodologies that can be scaled depending on the project size and its criticality. Crystal clear is the lightest weight of the crystal family and is not suited for a life-critical project described in the scenario.

                              Question 8 of 50 Question ID: 506113413

                              Throughout the project, the agile coach has been continuously encouraging the development team to look for and implement small incremental improvements for the processes used by the team to develop project deliverables.

                              What does the agile coach refer to?

                              A
                              B
                              C
                              D

                              Correct Answer: B

                              Explanation:

                              The Japanese word 'Kaizen' means 'change for the better' or 'continuous improvement'. This is a process that is continually and incrementally being implemented by those that do the work of the project. It is considered a mindset that all workers should adopt in order to optimize processes over time.



                              Details for Each Option:

                              A

                              Incorrect. Muda is the Japanese word meaning 'waste' and is the metaphor used in lean manufacturing and the Toyota production system for activities that do not add value to the end product. Eliminating waste is one of the basic premises of lean manufacturing and value stream analysis.

                              B

                              Correct. Kaizen is a Japanese word meaning 'change for the better' or 'continuous improvement'.

                              C

                              Incorrect. Ishikawa diagrams, also called fishbone diagrams, herringbone diagrams, or cause-and-effect diagrams are causal diagrams created by Kaoru Ishikawa that show the causes of a specific event. Common uses of the Ishikawa diagram are product design and quality defect prevention to identify potential factors causing an overall effect.

                              D

                              Incorrect. Kanban is an agile product development method that is based in lean manufacturing and used to provide information to the development team using a pull system.

                              Exam Content Outline:

                              Domain: 2. Process
                              Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                              PM Approach: Agile / Hybrid

                              +Reference:

                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 3.4 THE TAILORING PROCESS

                                  Question 9 of 50 Question ID: 506112791

                                  A project to develop a medical device has an aggressive timeline. The project scope will be decomposed into a WBS during initial planning, and the device will be developed iteratively and incrementally. The final product must comply with all government health and safety requirements before it can receive regulatory compliance approval.

                                  What is the best strategy to balance the needs of the project and the regulatory requirements?

                                  A
                                  B
                                  C
                                  D

                                  Correct Answer: B

                                  Explanation:

                                  The scenario describes a project that will combine elements of predictive and agile methodologies, making this a hybrid project. The output of each iteration will be an increment of the product. The project team will need to ensure that the product meets all of the requirements for regulatory approval. While the governmental regulatory body is only concerned with the final product, the project team should still verify that each product increment meets any requirements specific to that product increment. Deliverables (even interim deliverables) are verified as part of the Control Quality process. If the Control Quality process uncovers a nonconformance issue, it is best to discover that issue during the iteration so that steps can be taken to avoid the issue in future product increments. Waiting until after the complete product has been developed to verify it meets requirements will increase the risk of rework and may delay the project.



                                  Details for Each Option:

                                  A

                                  Incorrect. The iteration planning meeting is a collaborative event in which the team plans the work that will be completed during the iteration. The team would not be verifying deliverables during this meeting.

                                  B

                                  Correct. Verified deliverables are an output of the Control Quality process. The development team should verify that the product increment created during each iteration meets the project and regulatory requirements.

                                  C

                                  Incorrect. While there is nothing wrong with requesting that a government representative join the project team, this answer choice is unlikely to be realistic, nor is it clear how exactly this action will balance the needs of the project and the regulatory requirements as requested by the question.

                                  D

                                  Incorrect. Validation of deliverables is part of customer acceptance. Verification of deliverables is performed by the project team to ensure the deliverables meet the established requirements. Deliverables should be verified before they are validated.

                                  Exam Content Outline:

                                  Domain: 3. Business Environment
                                  Task: 3.1 Plan and manage project compliance
                                  PM Approach: Agile / Hybrid

                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES
                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.3.4 CONSIDERATIONS FOR SELECTING A DEVELOPMENT APPROACH
                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.7.2.1 Deliverable Metrics
                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 3.3.1 LIFE CYCLE AND DEVELOPMENT APPROACH SELECTION
                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 3.3.2 PROCESSES
                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 3.3.4 TOOLS

                                      Question 10 of 50 Question ID: 508115028

                                      During a quality management review of a highly complex pharmaceutical project, your team discovers that the testing process for a critical drug component is not adequately aligned with regulatory standards. Failure to comply with these standards could have severe legal and financial consequences. The project is already behind schedule, and the budget is constrained.

                                      What is the project manager's best approach to address this issue?

                                      A
                                      B
                                      C
                                      D

                                      Correct Answer: B

                                      Explanation:

                                      The best first step is Answer B: Conduct a comprehensive risk assessment and revise the quality management plan. Here’s why: Risk Identification and Assessment - Before reallocating resources, escalating, or halting production, the project manager must analyze the severity, probability, and impact of non-compliance. This ensures decisions are based on evidence rather than reaction. Updating the Quality Management Plan - The PMBOK® Guide emphasizes that the Quality Management Plan should align with both project objectives and external regulatory requirements. Revising the plan integrates compliance into all processes and avoids future misalignments. Balanced Decision-Making - Since the project already faces schedule and budget constraints, the risk assessment provides a foundation to prioritize regulatory compliance while managing competing constraints. This avoids overreaction (halting production) or blind fixes (reallocating resources without impact analysis). Strategic Alignment - Revising the plan ensures compliance is embedded in the delivery system, thereby protecting value delivery, satisfying governance expectations, and ensuring long-term sustainability of project outcomes.



                                      Details for Each Option:

                                      A

                                      Incorrect: Escalate to senior management - Escalation without a risk assessment lacks clarity. Senior management would need structured information about severity, alternatives, and trade-offs. Escalating too early shifts accountability without adding value.

                                      B

                                      The correct answer is B. Conducting a comprehensive risk assessment ensures the project manager understands the full implications of non-compliance and can strategically update the quality management plan. This approach aligns the project with regulatory requirements while minimizing disruptions to other areas. Escalating (A) or reallocating resources (C) without a detailed analysis may lead to suboptimal decisions, and halting production (D) could unnecessarily exacerbate delays and costs.

                                      C

                                      Incorrect: Reallocate resources from other areas - While it prioritizes compliance, doing so without an impact analysis could jeopardize other critical deliverables, potentially leading to cascading project risks.

                                      D

                                      Incorrect: Halt production immediately - This is a drastic, reactive measure. Halting could trigger unnecessary delays and financial losses before understanding whether interim mitigation strategies exist. Stopping production should only follow a risk-based decision.

                                      Exam Content Outline:

                                      Domain: 2. Process
                                      Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                                      PM Approach: Predictive

                                      +Reference:

                                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
                                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.8.5 RISK
                                      Process Groups: A Practice Guide, Project Management Institute Inc., 2023, 5.1 Develop Project Management Plan
                                      Process Groups: A Practice Guide, Project Management Institute Inc., 2023, 7.7 Control Quality

                                          Question 11 of 50 Question ID: 506110095

                                          As you perform quality assurance for a project to develop a new autopilot feature for a vehicle, you have created the diagram below, which compares the vehicle speed with uncommanded lane departures.

                                          What can be said about this diagram?

                                          A
                                          B
                                          C
                                          D

                                          Correct Answer: B

                                          Explanation:

                                          A scatter diagram is a data representation technique that may be used as part of quality assurance. A scatter diagram, as presented in the question, is a graph that shows the relationship between two variables. The diagram shown in the question demonstrates very close proximity between the data points and the trendline, which indicates a strong correlation between the two variables. Therefore, we can surmise that the defect rate (lane departures) increases as speed increases.



                                          Details for Each Option:

                                          A

                                          Incorrect. An affinity diagram organizes potential causes of defects into groups showing areas that should be focused on the most. The diagram presented by the question shows the relationship between two variables. Therefore, this answer choice can be eliminated.

                                          B

                                          Correct. The diagram presented by the question is a scatter diagram. This diagram demonstrates very close proximity between the data points and the trendline, which indicates a strong correlation between the two variables.

                                          C

                                          Incorrect. The diagram from the question shows the relationship between two variables. An affinity diagram organizes potential causes of defects into groups showing areas that should be focused on the most, making this an incorrect response.

                                          D

                                          Incorrect. The diagram demonstrates very close proximity between the data points and the trendline, which indicates a strong, not weak, correlation between the two variables. Therefore, this response is incorrect.

                                          Exam Content Outline:

                                          Domain: 2. Process
                                          Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                                          PM Approach: Predictive

                                          A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES

                                              Question 12 of 50 Question ID: 506151403

                                              The quality management has been perfect for the project up to this point. Suddenly, the quality assurance (QA) lead who developed and performed most of the quality activities for the project has been temporarily reassigned to help another project.

                                              What should the project manager do?

                                              A
                                              B
                                              C
                                              D

                                              Correct Answer: C

                                              Explanation:

                                              The scenario describes the Manage Quality process. This process is sometimes called quality assurance. Manage Quality is the process of translating the quality management plans into executable quality activities. These activities can ideally be performed by anyone on the team with the proper training, guidance, and tools. In this scenario, the tools and methods used by the quality assurance lead for the quality activities have been working well. Any data captured from the activities can be used and analyzed to report the status of the project quality and control the quality, as needed. It is important for the project to continue these activities as part of the Manage Quality process throughout the project. Unfortunately, the project can not use its current subject matter expert (SME) but should seek alternatives, such as reassigning another resource to the task(s). In any case, the quality activities should not cease or pause due to a resource change. Therefore, of the available options, assigning another team member to carry out the originally planned quality activities is the best answer to the question asked.



                                              Details for Each Option:

                                              A

                                              Incorrect. While it is reasonable to assume that some of the project work will be impacted by the departure of the QA lead, there is not enough information in the question to determine if the cost or schedule baseline will need to be modified. It is possible that the project has contingency reserves allocated for this risk (if it was identified during project planning) or another QA specialist can be acquired to fulfill the role. Anyway, without having more information, one can only speculate about the need for the change request.

                                              B

                                              Incorrect. The quality management has been working well. There is no indication that the quality activities need to change.

                                              C

                                              Correct. The quality activities are working and should continue. Since the question does not indicate that the QA lead possesses unique knowledge, another project team member can take over conducting these activities; or if one on the team is not available or does not possess even basic quality assurance skills, the project manager may need to acquire an outside resource for this activity.

                                              D

                                              Incorrect. The QA lead has been reassigned to another project. The timeline for the QA lead's return is unknown or may not happen at all. Suspending quality activities does not assure the quality of the project continues.

                                              Exam Content Outline:

                                              Domain: 1. People
                                              Task: 1.4 Empower team members and stakeholders
                                              PM Approach: Predictive

                                              +Reference:

                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 2.3.5 APPLY EXPERTISE
                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.2 CREATE A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT TEAM ENVIRONMENT
                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.6 DEMONSTRATE LEADERSHIP BEHAVIORS
                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES
                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.9 NAVIGATE COMPLEXITY
                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.2.1 PROJECT TEAM MANAGEMENT AND LEADERSHIP
                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3.1 Cost of Quality

                                                  Question 13 of 50 Question ID: 506151420

                                                  The project manager and members of the project team start an Ishikawa diagram for a quality issue. Someone writes down 'source material' as a potential cause.

                                                  What is the next best action for the project manager?

                                                  A
                                                  B
                                                  C
                                                  D

                                                  Correct Answer: B

                                                  Explanation:

                                                  An Ishikawa diagram is a quality management tool that can be used as part of the Manage Quality process or Control Quality process to assist in the brainstorming, discussion, and examination of potential causes to a problem, issue, or other quality concern. Ishikawa diagrams are also referred to as cause-and-effect diagrams, why-why diagrams, and fishbone diagrams - due to the resemblance of a fish skeleton with the problem at the head and possible causes branching out. Similar to a mind map, Ishikawa diagrams can extend out and are shaped by the input of the team. There is no correct path. It is an exercise to brainstorm and ask how and why. After the tool stimulates enough thinking, the targeted causes from the diagram can be examined further with follow up actions suggested. Until then, the project manager should encourage and facilitate more brainstorming and good discussion.



                                                  Details for Each Option:

                                                  A

                                                  Incorrect. Ishikawa diagrams and other cause-and-effect diagrams are used to assist the team to brainstorm, discuss, and examine potential reasons or causes for a quality problem. Writing down a possible cause is the start, not the end point requiring immediate action.

                                                  B

                                                  Correct. The purpose of a cause-and-effect diagram such as the Ishikawa is to brainstorm various possibilities and connections to potential causes to a problem, issue, or other quality concern. The project manager should encourage the process to continue.

                                                  C

                                                  Incorrect. The Ishikawa diagram and the cause-and-effect diagram are essentially the same. Other names include fishbone diagrams and why-why diagrams.

                                                  D

                                                  Incorrect. Ishikawa diagrams can examine the process and the product. It can focus both internally on the project organization and operations as well as the customer or other external sources.

                                                  Exam Content Outline:

                                                  Domain: 2. Process
                                                  Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                                                  PM Approach: Predictive

                                                  +Reference:

                                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES
                                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
                                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 4.4.1 DATA GATHERING AND ANALYSIS
                                                  Process Groups: A Practice Guide, Project Management Institute Inc., 2023, 6.3 Manage Quality
                                                  Process Groups: A Practice Guide, Project Management Institute Inc., 2023, 7.7 Control Quality
                                                  Process Groups: A Practice Guide, Project Management Institute Inc., 2023, 10 Tools and Techniques
                                                  End Exam

                                                      Question 14 of 50 Question ID: 506113813

                                                      A product owner is giving an agile presentation at a meeting for some senior project stakeholders. One of the attendees asks him what he believes is the main benefit of using an agile method on a project. The product owner explains that following agile principles when executing a project helps the project team to detect problems early and often, and allows more opportunities and time to address problems before they become even bigger issues.

                                                      What aspect of Agile enables this type of problem detection?

                                                      A
                                                      B
                                                      C
                                                      D

                                                      Correct Answer: B

                                                      Explanation:

                                                      One of the major success factors of any agile project is utilizing a combination of incremental development with reflection. Incremental development refers to a scheduling and staging strategy in which pieces of the system are developed at different rates or times and integrated as they are developed. Incremental development lets the team learn about its own development process as well as about the system being designed. After a section of the system is built, the team members reflect on their working conventions to find out what should be improved. Without incremental development, the team does not have a chance to detect and correct problems in its direction and process. Without reflection, the team will not actually redirect itself.



                                                      Details for Each Option:

                                                      A

                                                      Incorrect. These are aspects of a 'heavy' methodology, where agile is a 'light' methodology concerned with minimizing the amount of documentation, process, and formality used on a project.

                                                      B

                                                      Correct. Without incremental development, the team does not have a chance to detect and correct problems in its direction and processes. Without reflection, the team will not actually redirect itself.

                                                      C

                                                      Incorrect. A random organizational paradigm is a type of organizational structure without central leadership that sometimes works for small teams but is not characteristic of agile methods.

                                                      D

                                                      Incorrect. Agile dictates the opposite and encourages a project team to fail early since this will help them learn from their mistakes and improve future iterations.

                                                      Exam Content Outline:

                                                      Domain: 2. Process
                                                      Task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
                                                      PM Approach: Agile / Hybrid

                                                      +Reference:

                                                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.3.3 DEVELOPMENT APPROACHES
                                                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.8 UNCERTAINTY PERFORMANCE DOMAIN
                                                      Agile Practice Guide - First Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2017, 2.4 UNCERTAINTY, RISK, AND LIFE CYCLE SELECTION
                                                      Agile Software Development: The Cooperative Game, Second Edition, Alistair Cockburn, 2007, Problem Solving - Problem Detection
                                                      End Exam

                                                          Question 15 of 50 Question ID: 506112980

                                                          Your project is to design a payroll automation system for a client company. You have assured the client that the system contains all of the state-of-the-art features to protect it against modern threats. The client has asked you to perform a penetration test in order to validate your claim.

                                                          The cost to perform this test is an example of which of the following?

                                                          A
                                                          B
                                                          C
                                                          D

                                                          Correct Answer: D

                                                          Explanation:

                                                          Penetration testing is a technique to test the deterrence of a system against hacking attempts. This technique is typically a costly activity and requires time and expertise. Testing is performed to assess the quality of a system and is considered appraisal costs. Appraisal costs fall under the cost of conformance category and are an example of the data analysis techniques that can be used as part of the Plan Quality Management process.



                                                          Details for Each Option:

                                                          A

                                                          Incorrect. Cost plus fixed fee is a type of cost-reimbursable procurement contract where the client pays for allowable expenses as well as a fee that does not change, being based on a percentage of the original estimated project costs. The cost to perform a penetration test is not an example of a contract.

                                                          B

                                                          Incorrect. Cost of changes refers to the cost of making changes and correcting errors throughout a project life cycle. The cost of the penetration test is not related to changes or errors.

                                                          C

                                                          Incorrect. It would be considered the cost of non-conformance if the system had already failed such that you may incur cost for rework or scrapping work if the failures were found by the project. Non-conformance may also include additional liabilities, warranty work or lost business if the failures were found by the customer. The penetration test requested by the customer does not fall under any of these categories, making the cost of nonconformance an incorrect answer.

                                                          D

                                                          Correct. Penetration testing is an appraisal cost to assess the quality of the work product. It is money spent to avoid failure in satisfying customer requirements. This falls under the cost of conformance.

                                                          Exam Content Outline:

                                                          Domain: 2. Process
                                                          Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                                                          PM Approach: Predictive

                                                          +Reference:

                                                          A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES
                                                          A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
                                                          A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3.1 Cost of Quality
                                                          Process Groups: A Practice Guide, Project Management Institute Inc., 2023, 5.14 Plan Quality Management
                                                          Process Groups: A Practice Guide, Project Management Institute Inc., 2023, 10 Tools and Techniques

                                                              Question 16 of 50 Question ID: 506113804

                                                              During project execution, team members recommend using a process that will allow individual work packages produced by one project team member to be evaluated by another team member in order to determine if the work conforms to documented standards.

                                                              Which of the following do the team members recommend?

                                                              A
                                                              B
                                                              C
                                                              D

                                                              Correct Answer: C

                                                              Explanation:

                                                              Peer reviews, audits, walkthroughs, or just reviews, are all different names of inspection, one of the tools and techniques used in several project management processes, such as Validate Scope or Control Quality. Peer reviews examine the work product to determine whether it conforms to documents standards. While the PMBOK® Guide does not specify that the peer review should be performed by the members of the same team as described in the scenario, such practice is acceptable and does not diminish the validity of the correct answer.



                                                              Details for Each Option:

                                                              A

                                                              Incorrect. Cross-pollination is the transfer of pollen from the flower of one plant to the flower of a plant having a different genetic constitution. Cross-pollination is not related to project management as far as the PMBOK® Guide is concerned.

                                                              B

                                                              Incorrect. Performance reviews measure, compare and analyze actual project performance against the baseline rather than evaluating individual deliverables against the documented standards - a practice which is more accurately described by peer reviews.

                                                              C

                                                              Correct. A peer review is the inspection or examination of a work product or activities to determine if it conforms to documented standards. Of the choices provided, peer review best describes what the team members suggest in the scenario, making the peer review the best answer to the question asked.

                                                              D

                                                              Incorrect. Osmotic communication, or close communication, refers to the useful information that flows between team members working in close proximity to each other. Osmotic communication has little or nothing to do with what the team members suggest.

                                                              Exam Content Outline:

                                                              Domain: 2. Process
                                                              Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                                                              PM Approach: Predictive

                                                              +Reference:

                                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.2 CREATE A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT TEAM ENVIRONMENT
                                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES
                                                              A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.2.3 HIGH-PERFORMING PROJECT TEAMS

                                                                  Question 17 of 50 Question ID: 506113246

                                                                  In an organization, project teams develop and follow their quality management plans. However, almost all quality activities are focused on the effective use of project processes with very little time spent on product design and process improvement.

                                                                  What should you recommend to improve the way quality is approached in the organization?

                                                                  A
                                                                  B
                                                                  C
                                                                  D

                                                                  Correct Answer: B

                                                                  Explanation:

                                                                  The question implies that the project teams are performing the Manage Quality process. Manage Quality is sometimes called quality assurance, although in project management Manage Quality has a broader scope. Quality assurance is focused on the project processes and ensuring that they are used effectively. Manage Quality includes all the quality assurance activities but is also concerned with project design aspects and process improvements. According to the scenario, almost all quality activities are focused on the effective use of project processes, with very little time spent on product design and process improvement. This means only one area of the Manage Quality process is covered. Therefore, to help the company to improve project quality, you should recommend that their project teams cover all of these quality components by refocusing on the Manage Quality process.



                                                                  Details for Each Option:

                                                                  A

                                                                  Incorrect. You are already focusing almost exclusively on quality assurance activities, which is primarily about using project processes effectively.

                                                                  B

                                                                  Correct. The Manage Quality process includes all the quality assurance activities but is also concerned with project design aspects and process improvements. By focusing on the Manage Quality process, you cover all of these.

                                                                  C

                                                                  Incorrect. Rewards and recognition are among the tools and techniques of the Develop Team process used to encourage and support desirable behavior. There is not enough information in the question to determine if there is a lack of rewards and recognition or to ascertain if or how the team's behavior correlates with successfully managing quality.

                                                                  D

                                                                  Incorrect. The quality management activities can be performed internally, externally, or as a combination. However, it is the 'what' of the quality management content that determines if the quality management on a project is adequate.

                                                                  Exam Content Outline:

                                                                  Domain: 2. Process
                                                                  Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                                                                  PM Approach: Predictive

                                                                  +Reference:

                                                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, The Standard for Project Management: 3.8 BUILD QUALITY INTO PROCESSES AND DELIVERABLES
                                                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3 QUALITY
                                                                  A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 2.6.3.1 Cost of Quality
                                                                  Process Groups: A Practice Guide, Project Management Institute Inc., 2023, 6.3 Manage Quality

                                                                      Question 18 of 50 Question ID: 506113286

                                                                      You are managing a process improvement project and have interviewed different stakeholders over the past few weeks to understand the various suppliers, products supplied, manufacturing steps, and inputs and outputs. You are now in a very good position to start analyzing the processes.

                                                                      What should you do next?

                                                                      A
                                                                      B
                                                                      C
                                                                      D

                                                                      Correct Answer: D

                                                                      Explanation:

                                                                      According to the scenario provided, you are performing the Plan Quality Management process. You have obtained enough information regarding your customer's processes to enable you to start analyzing them, and the next step is to visually document the processes using a data representation tool, such as a flowchart. The SIPOC (suppliers, inputs, processes, outputs, customers) model is an example of a flowchart that is specifically designed for analyzing suppliers and process interactions in a manufacturing environment and, of the choices provided, is the best tool to use.



                                                                      Details for Each Option:

                                                                      A

                                                                      Incorrect. The cost of conformance is money spent during the project to avoid failure. Determining the cost of conformance provides the prevention component of the cost of quality, but this does not help with the analysis of specific processes or their interactions.

                                                                      B

                                                                      Incorrect. The cost of non-conformance is money spent during and after the project because of failures. Determining the cost of non-conformance provides the internal and external failure components of the cost of quality but does not help to analyze specific processes or their interactions.

                                                                      C

                                                                      Incorrect. Control charts are used to determine whether or not a process is stable using statistical plotting. However, they are not used for general process analysis.

                                                                      D

                                                                      Correct. SIPOC models are a type of flowchart designed to help visualize the interactions between suppliers, inputs, processes, outputs, and customers in a coherent value chain.

                                                                      Exam Content Outline:

                                                                      Domain: 2. Process
                                                                      Task: 2.7 Plan and manage quality of products/deliverables
                                                                      PM Approach: Predictive

                                                                      +Reference:

                                                                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 4.4.1 DATA GATHERING AND ANALYSIS
                                                                      A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) – Seventh Edition, Project Management Institute Inc., 2021, 4.6.6 VISUAL DATA AND INFORMATION
